posts.name: or eliran
posts.cooked: Perhaps a very basic question but i just now realize i never really understood the motovation of making a gearbox

There are several reasons that people make their own gearboxes.  The following are a few off the top of my head.

Versaplanetaries are limited in their allowable torque output.  So if you have a very large reduction high torque requirement a versaplanetary will likely not work property.   There are some off the shelf items that allow higher torque such as the Sport Gearbox and the MaxPlanetary, but they still have limitations.

Versaplanetaries are limited in their allowable torque output.  So if you have a very large reduction high torque requirement a versaplanetary will likely not work property.   There are some off the shelf items that allow higher torque such as the Sport Gearbox and the MaxPlanetary, but they still have limitations.

The packaging of a Versaplanetary or similar may not work well for the design and a custom solution might work better

The packaging of a Versaplanetary or similar may not work well for the design and a custom solution might work better

PTO - you do not see this as much now as in the past with the increase of power distribution slots and low weight of the brushless motors, but in the past many teams would have multi use motors that would say drive the robot then in endgame climb.  They would use a custom gearbox mechanism with a shifter and power takeoff to accomplish this.

PTO - you do not see this as much now as in the past with the increase of power distribution slots and low weight of the brushless motors, but in the past many teams would have multi use motors that would say drive the robot then in endgame climb.  They would use a custom gearbox mechanism with a shifter and power takeoff to accomplish this.

Adding brake mechanisms.  It is often best to add a friction brake at on one of the higher speed shafts or lower torque shafts in a gear reduction.  This can be done on a custom parallel shaft gearbox, but would be quite challenging on a stacked planetary.

Adding brake mechanisms.  It is often best to add a friction brake at on one of the higher speed shafts or lower torque shafts in a gear reduction.  This can be done on a custom parallel shaft gearbox, but would be quite challenging on a stacked planetary.

It is not too difficult to do with off the shelf gears available and a CNC router.  It makes for some really neat custom and cool looking pieces and can teach a lot of design practices to students.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: Versa’s are great. But they are relatively fragile so it is not the last gear box you will ever need. FRC is largely a learning opportunity. There is value in the exercise of designing a gear box. Sometimes a custom solution fits the packaging better. Insert your teams reason here.

posts.name: Jacob Frye
posts.cooked: If you have to use multiple motors custom is the best way to go

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
Different applications require different packaging. I would also say that until the MAXPlanetary came out I didn’t feel like we had a reliable option for high-torque motors. I was able to run a 3-stage MP gearbox off a Falcon last year with a final drive chain reduction and never had a failure.

Learning opportunities is obviously a big factor if you have a design team that is ready to take on the challenge of doing custom spur gearboxes it be a valuable experience.

I would also posit weight as a reason…because of the availability of pocketed gears you likely could build a spur gearbox for a given application with the same ratio of a planetary gearbox and it could weigh less.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
Personally, most of my custom gearboxes are more replacements for other types of gearboxes, not so much planetary gearboxes.

If you need a large reduction and/or something compact for use with a single motor, you use a planetary gearbox.

If you need to use 2x Falcon 500 motors to drive a shaft on a ~2:1 ratio, then it’s easier to slap a few spur gears between two pieces of polycarbonate or aluminum. Using a planetary gearbox in this scenario would be inefficient because you would need two of them running at their lowest ratio and would likely be heavier and take up more space, it would also cost significantly more, as long as you have the manufacturing capability to make accurate hole patterns.
